author: theChad802
body:
I've tried 3 times to post this in a new thread, but it never gets approved I guess. So here is the story I want to share with you all.

-80% to +40% lifetime swapping from mostly bear to mostly bull recently.

[https://imgur.com/a/Q3xvUK7](https://imgur.com/a/Q3xvUK7)

I joined both WSB and Robinhood a little over 3 months ago during the  whole SPCE TO THE MOON!!! period and made some modest gains (that teeny  tiny bump at the start) and proceeded to baghold too long and sell for a  loss. Then after a series of bad plays (again, holding too long) and  mistimed puts,  I started pouring more and more money in to try to  recoup the losses but kept losing. What started as a deposit of my \~$600  tax return to play around with became a $13k nightmare.

Anyway,  eventually I went full bull at the bottom, and was able to recover it  all much quicker than I lost it. At peak, I was down -80% all time and  from yesterday to today alone, I went from -38% to +40%. I'll be cashing  out my initial investment + a bit extra so it's all play money from  here.

Positions that won big:

RTX, SPY, FB, ACB, DKNG, NAT **calls**

Positions that lost big:

USO, NAT, AL, CHGG **calls**

SNAP, AAPL, GILD, CHGG, CRM, SPY **puts**

What I learned:

\- Don't chase dips you aren't VERY confident about

\- Usually but not always inverse WSB

\- Don't bet against America

author: michaelchao3000
body:
There are different kinds of cloud companies that operate at different levels of the cloud: infrastructure-as-service, platform-as-a-service, software-as-a-service, data centers, companies that manufacture the server components, consultant companies that build and maintain cloud systems for their clients. 

Make sure you understand what category each cloud company falls under. Some examples are..

Infrastructure-as-a-service - AMZN, FSLY, MDB
Platform-as-a-service - MSFT, DDOG, SPLK, ZS
Software-as-service - CRM, PLAN, AVLR, SPOT

As always, do your own research and reach your own convictions about why you would buy and hold these companies long-term through any short-term volatility. The money will be made on holding them as they scale and grow over years and even decades, not trading in and out each day. Best wishes to you on your investing journey!

author: gnsmsk
body:
TL;DR: As an investor, here is what you are betting on if you decide to invest in Snowflake.

  1. Data analysis is going to be important more than ever to get competitive advantage as a company. Data is the new oil as they say.
  2. Big companies spent and continue to spend billions to build their data analytics platform (and now selling these to other big names and SMEs)
  3. Other big names and SMEs will need to spend some of their revenue on analytics to better understand their customers and improve their products/services
  4. They will look for a cheap, easy to use analytics platform that integrates well with known apps, tools, technologies and platforms that they have been using, such as Google Sheets/Excel, relational databases, text files, salesforce, you name it.
  5. Snowflake will be the go-to platform for these needs and my investment will grow fast with the company.

Now read the rest if you are bored and want to get bored even more.
Some facts first:

  * There are two major types of databases: transactional and analytical. Analytical data often comes from transactional data after it is transformed, enriched, joined etc.

  * Snowflake is an analytical database.

  * Amazon and Microsoft provide both types of databases on their respective platforms, AWS and Azure. 

So, as a company if your enterprise apps are hosted on AWS it makes sense to use their transactional database, called Aurora, for your apps. If you are on Azure, the equivalent would be SQL Server. **Snowflake replaces neither of these.**

Now, if you also want to invest in data analysis as a company (because this is where you get competitive advantage), then you hire a few data engineers/analysts/scientists and provide them an analytics platform. The database component of that platform has to be an analytical database and that is where Snowflake shines. 

As stated in the quote you shared, your data engineer pulls large amounts of data across multiple cloud platforms (mostly transactional databases but also other online services like SAP, Salesforce, Google Analytics etc) and puts it in an analytical database. Then your analyst/scientist analyzes it. For a company, if they are already using AWS or Azure it makes sense to get the analytical database from the same platform (for compatibility, support etc), namely Redshift in AWS and Data Warehouse (what a boring name) in Azure. 

This is another area where Snowflake continues to shine. See, they built their platform on the shoulders of giants: AWS and Azure. Behind the scenes, they actually use these platforms to store and process your data. This is a very wise decision because:

  * it enables them to scale without any additional work
  * it makes it easier for companies to switch to Snowflake as if it is a native component of those platforms. 
  * it makes the service very cheap from the day 1
  * they pose as an ally to the giants rather than a rival that needs to be crushed before it steals too much of their share. It is win-win-win scenario.

On top of all these, they have built an excellent platform which any data engineer/analyst/scientist would be pleased to use.

author: Waffini
body:
I am long on alteryx, but they need to expand their stack or they'll be priced out.
Tableau has already a good share in the data visualization area, expanding into the analytics space occupied by alteryx and soon the integration will Salesforce will become even more relevant, I can easily see Salesforce installations bringing tableau as part of the deal, effectively cutting out alteryx.
In the meantime, alteryx is a standalone product that comes with a hefty price tag for the desktop version.
Imho they need a) move the client to cloud b) increase collaboration capabilities (now you need to save and share the workflow file) c) expand the stack vertically either in the reporting direction, or ETL one.

author: 0000GKP
body: I was reading an article about my state's COVID-19 contact tracing that mentioned Salesforce CRM software. I did a little reading on Salesforce and saw mention of a software company that Salesforce partners with called Snowflake. Snowflake is about to IPO. A little more reading on Snowflake led me to a podcast called Rise of the Data Cloud where the CEO of Snowflake was talking about how all these tech companies collect obscene amounts of data, but all that data is kept in each individual's company's realm. Snowflake developed or is working on a platform to make all that data compatible and interchangeable between companies or individuals. Pretty interesting stuff. I started looking to see what kind of funds were holding Salesforce stock, and that led me to Information Technology sector funds. The same funds that hold Salesforce also  hold Apple, Microsoft, VISA, Mastercard, Adobe, and other very large companies. I bought some VGT at Vanguard.

author: quartzcrisis
body: It's not a big chunk of my investment which is generally in pretty stable stocks/etfs (VOO, QQQ, MSFT, AAPL, AMD, ATVI, CRM, NET). My goals are long term for the above investments. Ford was more of just a shot in the dark to see some larger percentage gains, same as my investments in PLUG (bought at $2.83) and TRTX (bought at $2.85). So my risk tolerance for this particular Ford trade is pretty high. My problem is that I do not know enough to make an informed decision about their potential as a business going forward. I suppose my timeline could be 10 years if holding it would be worthwhile. I don't have a need for any of this investment money for the foreseeable future.

author: jamesewelch
body: Based on my experiences, once you go to Salesforce you're locked-in. It becomes too expensive to migrate your data to another platform (to recode any specialized forms, reports, modules, etc.). It's way more expensive than MS CRM (and I'm a fan of MS CRM), but it has the name that C-suite staff love to repeat because it sounds better than saying MSFT. It's good for at least 2-5 years. It'll retain most of their existing customers and just keep growing due to vendor lock-in.

author: ikover15
body:
If we call short term=daytrade
Mid term =1-3 weeks

If I find a stock with a large discrepancy between bid volume and ask volume I’ll buy the corresponding option and then exit the trade once the bid/ask volume evens out or turns against me.

Mid-term I follow about 10-15 stocks price movements and buy a call when its at the low end of its normal movements or a put at high end.
For example for the past 5 weeks or so Salesforce has been fluctuating pretty consistently between the low $170’s and low $180’s. The past few times it’s dropped into the low $170’s I’ve purchased a call with 10+ DTE. Bought puts at high $170’s low $180’s. Not HR trades but pretty easy money

author: amerricka369
body:
I was looking into software companies recently too and found the price multiples outrageous from a market cap perspective and profitability stance. Crowd strike for instance has a phenomenal and important product but lacks profitability and its market cap is many many multiples ahead of revenue and long term future projected profitability. Data dog can be copied but it has the first market leadership. If they can continue to eat market share as they have and continue to extend their offerings, it builds them a wider moat and leads to improved profitability and free cash flow. Much like what Salesforce has done. 
Despite really liking Okta, Slack, Zoom, etc, I can’t see them extending their offerings in a meaningful way which puts a ceiling on them from both revenue, market cap and long term sustainability.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
"However, if we really sit down and think about what has already happened and what is on the way for the rest of this year, I truly can't see this momentum going through 2020 and into 2021"

People said that in March and April too. I think that there will be a rotation out of growth (I know there's part of this sub that hates to hear this because it doesn't go with their "everything is awful" narrative, but there are things that are doing quite well during this and those are growth stocks; Druckenmiller discussed this, there have been multiple conference calls discussing growth being pulled forward by "years" (such as Microsoft) and even the Salesforce call discussed how this situation has resulted in an unusual situation of companies that are very impacted and others not so much. 

I do think that there will be a rotation and probably a moderate correction would be healthy but I thought that in early May. You got a rotation out of growth that was swift last week and it lasted for about a day and a half before people piled back in again - the dip buyers were out n full force for things like TWLO.  

I do think that things aren't sustainable short-term. If I could have the kind of investment performance I've had for the first 6 months of the year repeated in the back half I'd be thrilled but I think that's highly unlikely unless this time is really awfully different. That said, long-term I think I've never been more excited about the prospects of the companies that I own. 

"3) "Unlimited" QE can only do so much:" 

John Hussman has fought the Fed for over a decade now and his "market neutral" fund has lost more than half its value and most of his AUM has fled. He has written countless, lengthy bear letters for years. Maybe he's eventually right, but which comes first, him being right or his fund closing? There has been this continued proclamation that "the Fed can't do anything more!" for years and then this happens and Powell basically goes, "Now witness the power of this fully operational and armed battle station."  The Fed cannot do everything, but they can do an awful lot and perhaps for longer than you think.

"How sustainable is it really?"

Part of this sub has been asking that for the last 40% or so. I've read what feels like a hundred "list of bad stuff that nobody seems to be paying attention to but me!" threads on here. This sub spent a month in a pointless debate about whether this was a "bull trap."

"I'm shorting the market using inverse ETFs. Who agrees?"

Just take profits and build some cash into strength. There have been a lot of very dismaying stories about people who have lost a lot shorting this and I do feel genuinely badly for the people who have lost a lot doing this. Maybe you will be lucky and time it right or maybe not but I'm not seeing what you feel is the catalyst to turn the market now.

Additionally, I genuinely do feel that this is a market of winners and losers and I do think that people should read conference calls and see what companies are saying rather than going on broad headlines but (shrug.) Additionally, some of the sectors that are impacted by this were already in decline before it and this pulled forward what might have been years of further slow decline into one or two. 

I don't agree with the selling everything (although I don't even know what you own) or nearly everything and piling into shorts (want to gradually sell some into strength and raise money to patiently wait for a better opportunity? fine) but good luck.

* Fastly has blown up to 370% and has become my largest holding
* Docusign 251%
* Zoom 150%
* Ringcentral 132%
* Square 105% (Bought this at $11, but have continued to add more)
* Spotify 74%
* Atlassian 70%
* Paypal 45%

Honestly, I invest in a lot of tech because it's what I have a better understanding of but a lot of these have been spiking due to COVID and I'm a bit worried about the valuations being too high.

Some of the things I bought in March/April that I'm hesitant about:

* Airlines (Alaskan, Delta, United, Southwest, Spirit, Hawaiian, and American in that order)
* Hotels (Hyatt, Marriott, Wynn, MGM in that order)
* Cruise lines
* Boeing (I've continued adding to this position)
* Ford
* Disney

Some others that I recently have added:

* ZoomInfo (decent weight, have a lot of faith)
* Cloudflare (small amount so far)

* Slack (have been in this from the start +14%, but I have a lot of faith in this in the mid-term and as an acquisition target)

Some of my largest and longest-term holdings:

* Amazon

* Paypal
* Netflix
* Apple
* Adobe

And then I have a lot more smaller holdings and of course index funds.

As for the others, my mistake I should've double checked my source.

It seems to be one of those auto-article generators from Yahoo which is why it's giving such oddly calculated margins.

author: zoltanyoursavior
body:
That's probably the reason I hate Salesforce so much. In a lot of ways they are doing what Intel did with the initial microprocessor. They lock in customers with contracts that cost millions to get out of, and if a customer wants to switch platforms, the cost of doing so is astronomical. Someone posted once how they tried to migrate their data from one platform to another and the company they were switching from was holding their data hostage until they covered the fees for migration. 

Until regulation steps in like it did in the cell phone carrier industry, these switching costs will likely get worse the more customers trust others with their data.

author: layinzer

author: Albedo100
body:
This is not uncommon. Dropbox has a 75% gross profit margin and has the same marketcap with over 5x the revenue. Even salesforce has that margin and is barely positive. 

I'm not convinced a company like Cloudflare and Fastly can just drop their sales and be profitable. Switching between CDNs is one of the easiest things a tech department can do. It's literally drag and drop stuff or a couple lines of code. It's not like using salesforce where it benefits from being an expert in it and you have an entire team developed around using it. 

CDN stocks are just a flavor of the season and are pumping high because of their low market caps.

author: StayClassynet
body:
I spent 10 years in ecomm selling personalization (web and email) and ecommerce platform software (ie. the website + shopping cart, inventory/promotion management etc.). My company was a partner of Avalara's for years.

I'm not familiar with AVLR's financials so I can't speak to how efficiently they are being run, but they are virtually guaranteed to continue their strong revenue growth. As it relates to the US ecommerce market, it's been the wild west since online shopping's inception. AVLR automates key tax processes & compliance by State, which as most would imagine differs significantly from one State to another and is a real pain in the ass for online retailers to keep up with changes/nuances/requirements/regulations. Up until the last few years, there hasn't been any governance around taxes for online shopping (even for large online retailers like Amazon). It sounds crazy, but a lot of online transactions haven't been taxed properly/correctly. That's starting to change and be monitored by Government, State by State and Avalara offers a great solution for this. With ecommerce adoption being further accelerated thanks to COVID, it stands to reason that an already growing industry (ecommerce) will continue to grow and AVLR stand to benefit nicely from this.

They are not the only players in this space (they do have lots of competition), but are easily one of the leading solution providers and have been for some time. One of the big keys to me for software like this is integration into other core ecommerce systems like payment processors/systems, ecommerce platform (ECP), order management (OMS), CRM/ERP/and more. AVLR do a really good job here.
